documents.document: @LenaBlixtSchmid Sure, but the tweet was a summary of @e_jgraham paper. Smell is powerful for memory, but far more subjective than other sensory precepts.

@pompei79 @ginlindzey Yeah, plaques. I assume there could be metal hanging bits on porticoes or facades, but with all the reconstruction, you’d have to go back to excavation photos (at least, at Ostia)... There are lead hangers between piers for ropes (?) on several portico sections.
@pompei79 @ginlindzey Yeah, @pompei79 is right! All come from funerary reliefs. Most are Isola Sacra & a few Porta Laurentina necropolis. There are ‘signs’ but just tools, horse & mill, etc.

@DianaJSpencer Yeah, I find the rhetoric of ‘urban history’ fascinating (even w/in academia). Small town monuments seem (anecdotally) to have direct relations to people in that place, but retail development is homogeneous capitalism... Sure it’s published.

@DianaJSpencer Depends how you define ‘central’. Suburbia & ‘walmartisation’ have pushed ‘centres’ out of small towns. This starts happening by the 1950s (if not earlier). More research yes...

Today: Deleuze & Guattari using sensory metaphors to describe social interactions none metaphorically... & relating their usage to functional defs of noise evident in Latin lit.
